title: An Automated Text Messaging Program to Inform Postoperative Opioid Prescribing
abstract:
A multidisciplinary group at the University of Pennsylvania Health System built, deployed, and tested an automated text messaging program for postoperative patient engagement. Patients provided e-consent immediately following surgery and then self-reported acute opioid use and pain intensity over 3 weeks. When brought to scale, this system provided a way to capture patient-reported outcomes and opioid use in real time. Next steps will focus on using the data to develop patient-informed and procedure-specific short-term opioid guidelines aimed at reducing the number of unused opioid tablets following surgery. 
 KEY TAKEAWAYS » The implementation of this approach in routine surgical care is novel in that it facilitates: (1) immediate and proactive remote follow-up; (2) remote consent; and (3) remote patientreported data collection. » Mobile engagement provides a scalable means of collecting real-time patient-reported outcomes and is inherently designed to be translated to other areas of health care. » Remote patient engagement and data capture using digital technologies require collaboration with platforms, dynamic and iterative processes, and continuous quality assessment. » Organizations that work to include key stakeholders, offload clinical providers, and develop feedback mechanisms can drive design and change in learning health systems.

sections.text: » Within the context of the opioid epidemic, we sought to investigate patient-reported outcomes in order to inform prescribing and empower clinicians to tailor their practice. To that end, we developed an automated text messaging system that has begun to generate powerful, specific data that will be used to mitigate the downstream impacts of unused opioid tablets in the community while ensuring that patients receive effective pain control.

sections.title: The Challenge
sections.text:
There continue to be significant opportunities to reduce excessive opioid prescribing, with one systematic review demonstrating that 42% to 71% of opioids that are prescribed for acute pain remain unused.  1  These prescriptions have also been associated with persistent use and misuse.  [2] [3] ] [4] [5] [6]  In the United States, a median of 20 opioid tablets is prescribed following common surgical procedures, compared with a median of one tablet in other countries.  7 To address this issue, state policies have been implemented to limit the number of opioids that can be prescribed acutely; however, these policies have been criticized as a one-size-fits-all approach that is disconnected from patient needs, potentially leading to uncontrolled pain.  [8] [9] 10] [11]  The challenge confronting clinicians centers on an attempt to balance pain management and opioid stewardship. Currently, clinicians lack pragmatic, patient-centered data to help them understand pain and opioid use in order to inform future prescribing practice. Research based on phone calls or paper surveys of patients' postoperative experiences can inform procedure-specific prescribing guidelines; however, such approaches are labor intensive, are not suited for continuous quality improvement, and are not scalable for the coverage of a breadth of prescribing indications.  [12] [13] [14] [15]  A gap persists in developing scalable methods that can both proactively engage patients to collect real-time data and support strategies to inform future care on a continuous basis. The Institute of Medicine's vision for learning health systems provides a framework for clinical challenges in which science, informatics, incentives, and culture align with improvement and innovation, with best practices seamlessly embedded in the delivery of care.  16 Digital technologies, such as text messaging, provide approaches to collect just-in-time data, to identify trends, and to address concerns early,  [17] [18] [19]  but applications for the promotion of opioid stewardship are limited.

" While clinicians do not wish to leave patients with intractable pain, they also do not intend to prescribe high numbers of prescription opioids. We believe that empowering providers with meaningful and actionable data, specific to their practice, is a key motivator for behavior change."

We hypothesized that: (1) text messaging would provide a simple approach to understanding patients' use of short-term opioids and allow for real-time monitoring of postoperative pain; and (2) these data ultimately could be used as a feedback mechanism and inform future prescribing. We hoped that such a strategy could effectively replace clinical intuition with patient-and procedurespecific information for short-term opioid prescribing and, more generally, that this approach could provide a framework for rapid, real-time data capture to inform health systems across a variety of clinical contexts.

sections.title: Pilot Strategies and Stakeholder Engagement
sections.text:
Our initial efforts focused on the feasibility of collecting patient-reported data that included the intensity of pain, the ability to manage pain, and the use of opioid analgesics. We started by calling patients within the first week after orthopedic procedures in order to assess whether they would be receptive to discussing their pain and the use of opioids immediately after surgery. On the basis of 80 telephone-based conversations, we quickly realized that: (1) patients were open to such discussions; and (2) the number of opioid tablets actually being used was lower than the number that had been prescribed.  20 While these findings were important, the process of making the calls, following up, and transcribing data was very labor intensive. Additionally, we knew that many more data would be needed to sufficiently identify central tendencies and reliably inform broader prescribing guidelines.

A "Fake Back-End" Approach

We then focused on developing a digital approach to capture these data from a larger population.

Given the ubiquity of text messaging,  21, 22  we translated our telephone script into a text-friendly format and tested it with the use of a "fake back-end" that simulated a computerized system; during this testing period, patients perceived that they were interacting with an automated system but, in reality, were simply texting with our team. This approach allowed our team to pilot the script, to iterate in real time, and to identify issues that otherwise would have resulted in poor or inconsistent data when brought to scale.

From here, the system continues along a fully automated workflow (Figure  1 ). Patients receive a series of messages beginning on postoperative day 4.

The initial message to patients accomplishes two critical goals: first, it introduces patients to the team and provides hyperlinked information for their review, and, second, it obtains patient consent for additional messaging and data capture. Patients reply with a simple "yes" to enroll, and then a series of conversational questions are triggered to be sent on postoperative days 4, 7, 14, and 21.

Patients can reply with a simple "no" to opt out at any point. In instances in which patients do not respond, they are sent a single reminder message within 30 minutes.

Branching logic takes patients through questions on self-reported pain intensity, the ability to manage pain, and the use of prescription opioids, while also providing nearby locations for safe opioid disposal. Patients reporting no current or future planned use are not sent additional messaging. The system includes several built-in scenarios to address clinical concerns (high pain, poor ability to manage pain, or high opioid use) and directs patients to contact their provider. These automated triggers provide a continuous means of directing patients to their clinical team for urgent concerns such as uncontrolled pain, the inability to effectively manage pain, and other unsolicited responses sent in via text messaging by the patient (Figure  2 ).

sections.title: Hurdles
sections.text: We have worked through multiple hurdles in terms of planning, implementation, and sustained execution.

sections.title: Planning
sections.text: Clinicians highlighted multiple concerns during the planning stage. Whereas the standard model relied on patients to contact providers with their questions, our approach involves reaching out to patients early, often, and remotely. As a result, concerns were raised that such increased interaction might lead to unintended consequences related to unscheduled care (e.g., increased telephone calls, ED visits, and refills of opioid prescriptions). Although our frontline teams have not noticed any such increases, we remain early in this work, and subsequent analyses at scale will investigate these important areas.

sections.title: Consent and Enrollment
sections.text:
We initially planned for providers to obtain signed, paper consent during the first preoperative visit. Uptake of in-person consent was slow (as was expected given the new approach), but, despite multiple efforts, enrollment and consent did not improve. We uncovered multiple roadblocks to obtaining consent: (1) the necessary documentation was not always present or easily accessible; (2) providers had short appointment windows; (3) providers lacked interest or simply forgot; and (4) signed consent forms were lost or were not scanned into the record.

" We hypothesized that: (1) text messaging would provide a simple approach to understanding patients' use of short-term opioids and allow for real-time monitoring of postoperative pain; and (2) these data ultimately could be used as a feedback mechanism and inform future prescribing."

Thus, obtaining patient consent in the office was a burden and a significant barrier. As a result, we partnered with our health system's leadership and legal and privacy offices to design a process that would ensure both patient privacy and secure data collection. The process begins with an introductory text message that contains no health information and allows patients to provide consent with a simple "yes" or "no" reply. The ability to decrease the logistic burdens placed upon already busy clinical staff and obtain e-consent has transformed our ability to scale our efforts.

sections.title: Implementation of a Texting Script
sections.text: Our fake back-end unearthed several issues related to the implementation of an automated script. First, in early testing, we found that some text messaging platforms were unable to simulate a conversation but rather, sent questions serially on the hour. Response rates improved when we were able to simulate a real-time conversation. Second, patients often responded in slang or with text that would be not be recognized by an automated system. Specifically, when prompted with

sections.title: NEJM CATALYST INNOVATIONS IN CARE DELIVERY 6
sections.text:
"please respond with a yes or no," patients often responded with multiple versions of "yes" (e.g., "yeah," "yep," or "yea"), and the platform needed to code these responses appropriately.

Third, as we moved toward a system that simulated conversations, we noticed a small number of patients asking questions related to a specific clinical concern. To address this issue, we built in prompts that directed patients to their clinicians with a simple one-tap phone call. Last, we noticed an unexpected drop in response rates as cellular carriers blocked hyperlink formats. Such hurdles reflected the need for continuous human quality assessment of the system for bounce notifications or unexpected drops in response rates.

sections.title: The Team
sections.text: Numerous individuals representing a wide range of roles were critical to the planning, design, implementation, and continuous improvement of the approach and text messaging program, including health care providers (surgeons, physicians, and advanced practice providers), research coordinators, health information systems analysts, data analysts, health services researchers, and patients. We also partnered with senior leadership from the areas of legal affairs, privacy, and data security in order to develop the methodology of reaching out to patients and obtaining consent digitally via text messaging. A clear and collaborative relationship with the text messaging platform services was also important, because flexibility in terms of content, timing, formatting, and data collection was key to the program's success.

sections.title: Metrics
sections.text:
Over a 16-month period (from September 2018 to January 2020), text messages were sent to 2,444 participants. Eligible individuals included adults (18 years of age or older) with a mobile device who had undergone a procedure in the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery and had received a prescription for an acute opioid. The primary outcome measures included the proportion of patients approached, the consent rate, and the response rate over time. Prior to e-consent, we were only able to identify and reach out to approximately one half of eligible patients; this limitation was attributed primarily to the challenges of having clinical staff attempt to approach patients.

"

The system includes several built-in scenarios to address clinical concerns (high pain, poor ability to manage pain, or high opioid use) and directs patients to contact their provider."

The creation of e-consent allowed us to reach out to all eligible patients, and the automated data collection system facilitated consistent participant engagement over time (Figure  3 ). Figure  4  displays the proportion of patients providing consent (47.2%) as well as the proportions of participants responding during the postoperative intervals (ranging from a low of 69% on day 7 to a high of 95% on day 21). Evaluation of the secondary measures (i.e., self-reported opioid use and pain intensity) revealed that, among respondents, 10,305 opioid tablets (61%) remained unused (Figure  5 ) and the mean self-reported pain score decreased across all procedure types within the first 21 days following surgery (Table  1 ).

sections.title: Next Steps
sections.text:
Building and Testing Patient-Informed Guidelines

The next key phase of this work will be to translate patient-reported data into procedure-specific opioid-prescribing guidelines that can be built into clinical workflows. Through the automated text messaging system, we have the ability to monitor and detect changes in prescribing, patientreported use, and pain scores in real time.

sections.title: Evaluating the Impact of Mobile Engagement on Patients and Health Systems
sections.text: We plan to broaden our efforts into other surgical departments in which acute opioids are being prescribed in order to explore the impact of mobile engagement on several critical metrics (e.g., quality, access, and cost), patient-centered outcomes (e.g., experience and communication), health care utilization (e.g., unscheduled care and prescription refills), and the ability to identify complications early in the postoperative period.

sections.title: Teamwork and Engagement
sections.text:
The success of our initiative hinged on a clear need, early collaboration with clinical providers, and health system leadership. It is important to note that while clinicians do not wish to leave patients with intractable pain, they also do not intend to prescribe high numbers of prescription opioids. We believe that empowering providers with meaningful and actionable data, specific to their practice, is a key motivator for behavior change.

"

The creation of e-consent allowed us to reach out to all eligible patients, and the automated data collection system facilitated consistent participant engagement over time."

With the support of our health system, we were able to obtain the appropriate legal and IT support that allowed us to work behind the scenes on enrollment, data capture, and analytics and thereby decrease the burden on clinical providers. Table  2  summarizes several key organizational and technical factors that learning health systems should consider when developing scalable methods for patient engagement and data collection. Adopting similar initiatives at other organizations will require early investments in these relationships in order to support long-term success. It should also be noted that our multidisciplinary team has a dedicated and shared focus on addressing the opioid epidemic. This type of strategic alignment helps foster collaboration across the health system. Table 2.
